title: 3 Best Methods for Cleaning Mirrors and Treating Tough Stains

steps.title: Combine equal parts white vinegar and warm water.
steps.content: Combine equal parts white vinegar and warm water. A mix of vinegar and water is one of the best ways to clean a foggy mirror. Make sure you’re using white vinegar specifically and not something like apple cider vinegar or wine vinegar. Pour the solution into a spray bottle and give it a good shake to make sure that everything is equally combined.

steps.title: Spray the solution and wipe your mirror from left to right.
steps.content: Spray the solution and wipe your mirror from left to right. Spray a liberal amount of your vinegar solution onto the mirror’s surface, starting at the top. Then, take something like a microfiber cloth and wipe across the mirror horizontally from left to right. Repeat this pattern until you reach the bottom. If your mirror has a wooden frame, avoid spraying the vinegar-water solution on the frame since it can get damaged. Another option is to spray the solution directly onto your cloth and then use it to wipe down the mirror. While vinegar isn’t toxic, still make sure that the room is well-ventilated as you work by opening a door or window, or by turning on a fan.

steps.title: Dry the mirror completely with a microfiber cloth.
steps.content: Dry the mirror completely with a microfiber cloth. Take a dry microfiber cloth and wipe over the surface of the mirror once again. Thoroughly dry the mirror to make sure you don’t leave behind any streak marks or drops of solution. A microfiber cloth is perfect for this step because it’s very absorbent and soft. Or, use a dry piece of newspaper. Just make sure the newspaper is a couple days or weeks old to ensure that the ink is completely dry and won’t smear everywhere. Another trick that can leave your mirror streak-free and prevent it from fogging up in the future is to apply shaving cream to the entire surface and then wipe it off with a microfiber cloth. steps.title: Mix ½ cup (118 ml) of ammonia with 2 cups (473 ml) of rubbing alcohol and a few drops of dish soap.
steps.content: Mix ½ cup (118 ml) of ammonia with 2 cups (473 ml) of rubbing alcohol and a few drops of dish soap. Stir everything to combine it evenly, then add enough warm water to bring the entire solution up to 1 gallon (3.8 L). Any mild dish soap will work for this cleaner. Once you’ve made the solution, pour it into a spray bottle . [2] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source If you don’t have rubbing alcohol or dish soap, just mix ½ cup (118 ml) of ammonia with 1 gallon (3.8 L) of warm water and mix. If you don’t have the supplies to make your own cleaner, using a glass cleaning product like Windex will get the job done just as well.

steps.title: Spray the cleaner onto your mirror and wipe with horizontal strokes.
steps.content: Spray the cleaner onto your mirror and wipe with horizontal strokes. Start by spraying your solution along the top of the mirror and use a microfiber cloth to wipe from left to right. Keep repeating this process until you reach the bottom. If your mirror has a wooden frame, avoid spraying the cleaner on it. Another option is to spray a microfiber cloth or rag with the cleaner and then wipe the mirror. Wear protective gear when cleaning with ammonia, even if it’s diluted with water. Wear rubber gloves and goggles , and leave the door open or turn on a fan to make sure the room is well-ventilated.

steps.title: Dry the mirror thoroughly with a microfiber cloth.
steps.content: Dry the mirror thoroughly with a microfiber cloth. To avoid leaving streak marks on your mirror, thoroughly dry the entire surface. Use something like a microfiber cloth since it’s an incredibly absorbent and soft material that won’t scratch your mirror. If you don’t have a microfiber cloth, use a dry piece of newspaper. Use a piece that’s a couple of days or weeks old to make sure that the ink is completely dried.

steps.title: Treat tough stains or residue with rubbing alcohol.
steps.content: Treat tough stains or residue with rubbing alcohol. If you have a hard water stain on your mirror or any gooey residue from something like a sticker, dampen a cloth or paper towel with rubbing alcohol and dab it over the spot. Let it sit for a minute or two, then wipe it off with a dry paper towel or microfiber cloth. Nail polish remover will also work just as well.

steps.title: Scrape off residue with a razor scraper.
steps.content: Scrape off residue with a razor scraper . Dampen the area with water, rubbing alcohol, or a vinegar solution made of equal parts white vinegar and warm water. Then, hold your razor at a 45-degree angle and scrape off the stain or residue marking up your mirror. Dry off the spot with a microfiber cloth or paper towel when you’re done.

steps.title: Apply a paste made with equal parts baking soda and vinegar.
steps.content: Apply a paste made with equal parts baking soda and vinegar. Baking soda is a safe and gentle cleaner that is great to use on glass. [3] X Research source Simply combine equal parts baking soda and white vinegar in a small bowl and mix them together until you get a paste. Apply the paste to the hard stain on your mirror, let it sit for a minute or two, then wipe it off with a clean cloth or towel. Only use white vinegar, not apple cider vinegar or wine vinegar.
